page.title: 04BOSCOBEL HOUSE
page.content: This historic house, now owned and administered by the English Heritage Trust, was once only a working farm. However, the family who owned it in 1642, when the Civil War began, were Roman Catholics, the Giffards. They identified with the cause of Charles 1 and the house was the scene of several skirmishes. It became nationally famous in 1662 when Charles II escaping from the Battle of Worcester, hid in the surrounding Oak forest, and later sheltered in the house. Since then, every owner allowed visitors to look at the tree. In the late nineteenth century the house began to be opened to the public. Now it is open all year round, and attracts visitors from all over the world.
